subject: Re: [junit] Question about test suites
msgSnippet: Sorry for the response lag too... @Inherited almost does it, but you need to make sure  the @Retention annotation is set to RUNTIME too or the  annotations
messageBody:
Sorry for the response lag too...

@Inherited almost does it, but you need to make sure the @Retention
annotation is set to RUNTIME too or the annotations will simply get
discarded. Looking at the current javadoc for Suite.SuiteClasses this
is almost there, and all you should need to do is put @Inherited at the
beginning. So something like this is in order:

@Inherited // <--- add this
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
@Target(ElementType.TYPE)
public static @interface Suite.SuiteClasses{ //rock on...

Thanks! And when can we expect a release? :o)

Jeff

> <mailto:jjg%40jqhome.net>> wrote:
> > Hi David!
> >
> > Here. Let us say that I had test classes, Test0, Test1. Each of these
> > requires a backend to be configured. I'd like to do something like this:
> >
> > @RunWith(Suite.class)
> > @...({Test0.class, Test1.class})
> > public abstract class MySuite{
> > abstract public void setBackend(Backend backend);
> >
> > @BeforeClass
> > public static void doSetup() throws Exception{
> > //... stuff to get this all pulled together and configure the tests
> > }
> > }
> >
> > Then all a tester needs to do is extend the class MySuite, implement the
> > method and s/he gets to run their backend against my tests.
> >
> > Complicating factors are that java does not allow for annotations to be
> > inherited unless the @interface is created with the @Inherited
> > annotation, so attempts to do what is above kick back the message that
> > there are no tests to run or some such. At least this is my
> > understanding of java annotations...
> >
> > The real life example has not just a couple of test classes, but many
> > more that very rigorously exercise the backend. The kludge is to have
> > the abstract MySuite class and have the annotations cut and pasted every
> > time. This is bad since it will make maintainability problematic (we
> > have lots of different backend configurations people want to test
> > against). What's more several people who want to use this really don't
> > know that much about jUnit and we'd really like it to be the case they
> > can write a backend then get good feedback on robustness, failure modes,
> > you name it.
> >
> > Is this clearer?
> >
> > Thanks in Advance!
> >
> > Jeff

> Maven. Now,
> >> > these run against a single backend and now several developers in my
> >> > group would like to use these tests against other backends to
> test them.
> >> > The most natural way to do this is with the test suite mechanism in
> >> > jUnit. That is to say, make up a suite that requires merely that the
> >> > backend be set and test away. Or so I thought.

> is going
> >> > to get deprecated soon, right? So that would be a deadend. Also, are
> >> > their plans to make annotations inheritable at some point in
> jUnit? We
> >> > could maybe live with cutting and pasting for the short term if
> we knew
> >> > that this issue would get resolved at some point.

> >> > Thanks!
